It was only in the shadow of the Columbia disaster that NASA realized that this was a more serious and deadly problem than they had thought before. We could probably launch 50 more shuttles under current conditions and not have another Columbia disaster, or it could happen on the very next flight. The difference is NASA is now watching for it closely, as seen with this last launch. Just like the peices of cloth fitting pulled from between the thermal tiles. Many shuttles have returned before with peices sticking out of the bottom of the shuttle, and there was never a serious concern about it. But now NASA is focussed on inspecting the vehicle before it returns to earth, rather than after it does. A leason no doubt learned from Columbia.

I think we are overlooking the point that both shuttle accidents are the indirect consequences of NASA getting the bargain basement option on the space shuttle with regard to its orbital boost stage.
 
 The Challenger disaster (frozen O-rings on the solid rocket booster) and Columbia (damage to leading edge of wing by foam shed from liquid fuel tank) are both linked to the design of the orbital boost stage- if NASA's proposal for a specific reusable boost vehicle had not been sidelined due to budget considerations the Shuttle system would have carried a much lower risk of an incident occuring at launch.
